MS.MIL.MPRT.KD-defenseArmsTrade.def: Arms transfers cover the supply of military weapons through sales, aid, gifts, and those made through manufacturing licenses. Data cover major conventional weapons such as aircraft, armored vehicles, artillery, radar systems, missiles, and ships designed for military use. Excluded are transfers of other military equipment such as small arms and light weapons, trucks, small artillery, ammunition, support equipment, technology transfers, and other services. Figures are SIPRI Trend Indicator Values (TIVs) expressed in US$ m. A '0' indicates that the value of deliveries is less than US$0.5m.
MS.MIL.MPRT.KD-defenseArmsTrade.name: Arms imports
MS.MIL.MPRT.KD-defenseArmsTrade.source: Stockholm International Peace Research Institute (SIPRI), Arms Transfers Programme (http://portal.sipri.org/publications/pages/transfer/splash).

MS.MIL.TOTL.P1-defenseArmsTrade.def: Armed forces personnel are active duty military personnel, including paramilitary forces if the training, organization, equipment, and control suggest they may be used to support or replace regular military forces.
MS.MIL.TOTL.P1-defenseArmsTrade.name: Armed forces personnel
MS.MIL.TOTL.P1-defenseArmsTrade.source: International Institute for Strategic Studies, The Military Balance.

MS.MIL.TOTL.TF.ZS-defenseArmsTrade.def: Armed forces personnel are active duty military personnel, including paramilitary forces if the training, organization, equipment, and control suggest they may be used to support or replace regular military forces. Labor force comprises all people who meet the International Labour Organization's definition of the economically active population.
MS.MIL.TOTL.TF.ZS-defenseArmsTrade.name: Armed forces personnel
MS.MIL.TOTL.TF.ZS-defenseArmsTrade.source: International Institute for Strategic Studies, The Military Balance.

MS.MIL.XPND.CD-defenseArmsTrade.def: Military expenditures data from SIPRI are derived from the NATO definition, which includes all current and capital expenditures on the armed forces.
MS.MIL.XPND.CD-defenseArmsTrade.name: Military expenditure
MS.MIL.XPND.CD-defenseArmsTrade.source: Stockholm International Peace Research Institute (SIPRI), Yearbook: Armaments, Disarmament and International Security.

MS.MIL.XPND.CN-defenseArmsTrade.def: Military expenditures data from SIPRI are derived from the NATO definition, which includes all current and capital expenditures on the armed forces, including peacekeeping forces; defense ministries and other government agencies engaged in defense projects; paramilitary forces, if these are judged to be trained and equipped for military operations; and military space activities. Such expenditures include military and civil personnel, including retirement pensions of military personnel and social services for personnel; operation and maintenance; procurement; military research and development; and military aid (in the military expenditures of the donor country). Excluded are civil defense and current expenditures for previous military activities, such as for veterans' benefits, demobilization, conversion, and destruction of weapons. This definition cannot be applied for all countries, however, since that would require much more detailed information than is available about what is included in military budgets and off-budget military expenditure items. (For example, military budgets might or might not cover civil defense, reserves and auxiliary forces, police and paramilitary forces, dual-purpose forces such as military and civilian police, military grants in kind, pensions for military personnel, and social security contributions paid by one part of government to another.)
MS.MIL.XPND.CN-defenseArmsTrade.name: Military expenditure
MS.MIL.XPND.CN-defenseArmsTrade.source: Stockholm International Peace Research Institute (SIPRI), Yearbook: Armaments, Disarmament and International Security.

MS.MIL.XPND.GD.ZS-defenseArmsTrade.def: Military expenditures data from SIPRI are derived from the NATO definition, which includes all current and capital expenditures on the armed forces, including peacekeeping forces; defense ministries and other government agencies engaged in defense projects; paramilitary forces, if these are judged to be trained and equipped for military operations; and military space activities. This definition cannot be applied for all countries, however, since that would require much more detailed information than is available about what is included in military budgets and off-budget military expenditure items. (For example, military budgets might or might not cover civil defense, reserves and auxiliary forces, police and paramilitary forces, dual-purpose forces such as military and civilian police, military grants in kind, pensions for military personnel, and social security contributions paid by one part of government to another.)
MS.MIL.XPND.GD.ZS-defenseArmsTrade.name: Military expenditure
MS.MIL.XPND.GD.ZS-defenseArmsTrade.source: Stockholm International Peace Research Institute (SIPRI), Yearbook: Armaments, Disarmament and International Security.

MS.MIL.XPND.ZS-defenseArmsTrade.name: Military expenditure

MS.MIL.XPRT.KD-defenseArmsTrade.def: Arms transfers cover the supply of military weapons through sales, aid, gifts, and those made through manufacturing licenses. Data cover major conventional weapons such as aircraft, armored vehicles, artillery, radar systems, missiles, and ships designed for military use. Excluded are transfers of other military equipment such as small arms and light weapons, trucks, small artillery, ammunition, support equipment, technology transfers, and other services. Figures are SIPRI Trend Indicator Values (TIVs) expressed in US$ m.  A '0' indicates that the value of deliveries is less than US$0.5m
MS.MIL.XPRT.KD-defenseArmsTrade.name: Arms exports
MS.MIL.XPRT.KD-defenseArmsTrade.source: Stockholm International Peace Research Institute (SIPRI), Arms Transfers Programme (http://portal.sipri.org/publications/pages/transfer/splash).
